games.name: Rapid Musicals
games.description: Players get a suggestion of a starting musical style. They start a song from the middle of a musical. A director rings a bell as *soon* as they feel we have a good idea what the musical is about. The musician should immediately starting playing a new style, while the performers justify both their position and the new musical by discovering what new musical they are in the middle of.
games.notes: This game benefits from the musician and the performers commiting heavily to the music, the dance, and the singing.

games.name: Rapid Scenes
games.description: Players start a scene from audience suggestion. After just a few seconds, the MC rings a bell. The performers must justify whatever position they are in by starting a new scene. Scenes rarely last longer than about 30 seconds.
games.notes: Once we know what is going on in a scene, there's little reason not to ring the bell. But the MC may let scenes breath a few seconds longer sometimes just to keep the performers on their toes. Good training for improvisers who are more used to long-form and less used to starting scenes in the middle of the action.

games.name: Realistic Scene
games.description: Improvisers play a scene for realism (fine line between "being real" and "being maudlin". We tend to over emote these scenes).

games.name: Reminiscence
games.description: One or more improvisers reminisce about event/people from the past. Other improvisers create the scene. The person reminiscing may weave in and out of the flashback.

games.name: Remote Control
games.description: An imaginary movie title is given and the action begins. At the discretion of an off stage improviser, "Fast Forward", "Rewind", "Slow Motion" are called out. The actors react accordingly.
variations: TV Remote Control: A scene begins. At some point, an off-stage voice "changes the channel." Improvisers momentarily freeze, and then start a new TV show based on their positions. Scene plays a bit, then the channel changes again. Off stage improviser then changes channels periodically between the three established shows.

games.name: Replacement
games.description: Play a two-person scene. If an improviser wimps, blocks, waffles, or doesn't accept an offer, they are replaced in the scene. This game helps to train you to listen and accept offers.

games.name: Research and Development
games.description: The improvisers ask for the name of a yet to be invented scene format. One of the improvisers takes the stage and provides an improvised definition of the format. Then the improvisers play the scene as defined. Great for finding new formats!

games.name: Return Department
games.description: A product and an unusual problem with the product are received from the audience. An unknowing improviser enters and is playing an employee in a return department of a store. An improviser then tries to endow them with the product and the problem.

games.name: Ritual
games.description: Everyday activity or object is played as if part of a ritualistic ceremony.

games.name: Scene By Numbers
games.description: An improviser gets a number from the audience. Scene is played using only numbers as dialogue, counting down from the number given by the audience. Scene ends at "zero."

games.name: Scene from Music
games.description: Scene starts with music provided by music improviser. One or more improvisers dance to the music. After a short period of time, the MC blows the whistle, dancers freeze in position. They then begin a scene based on their physical positions.
variations: Scene to Music: Improvisers perform a scene to music provided by a live musician or the music improviser. Can be played as a silent scene. Improvisers may choose to ask for a suggestion. Music may be played for the entire scene, cut off at some point, or changed during the course of the scene. If it changes, improvisers must justify the change.

games.name: Scene From Nothing
games.description: No suggestion is taken from the audience. There is no pre-planning of the scene. One improviser gets up on stage and the scene begins.

games.name: Scene From Something
games.description: Can't discuss on Bench what you are going to do. One person gets up, gets a suggestion from the audience, and begins.

games.name: Scene in Reverse
games.description: Scene starts at the end and moves to the beginning. Actions, conversations, all cause and effect relationships are reversed.
variations: Use a story that is already known (eg. Folk Tale in Reverse). Dialogue is spoken in the understandable vernacular.

games.name: Scene in the Dark
games.description: Situation is given. At the lighting improvisers discretion, the lights go out on stage at some point.
variations: Reverse Scene in the Dark: As above, except whenever the lights on stage are "on", the improvisers react as if they are in the dark. When on stage lights are "off", improvisers react as if the lights are on.

games.name: Scene Tag
games.description: Multiple playing areas (usually two) are established. A scene begins in one of the areas. When a player hears a line of dialogue they wish to use, they clap their hands and begin a scene in their area repeating that line as the first line of the scene. Once all the scenes have been established, then the scenes transition from one to another in any order by simply clapping and using the line of dialogue as their next line.
variations: Rather than clapping, the improvisers simply say the line and allow the original scene to play to a beat before beginning the next scene with that line of dialogue.

games.name: Scene Using the MC
games.description: Teams play a scene in which they use the MC as an integral part of the team

games.name: Scene Without _______
games.description: Possibilities are limitless. Scene is played, for reality, as if the world were without ____ (eg: words, emotions, contractions, gravity, a word, the letter "h", love, parents, food, etc.)

games.name: Scene Without Humans
games.description: Scene is played entirely without human characters appearing on stage.

games.name: Secret Word Endowments
games.description: Team members face upstage, plugging their ears. MC asks the audience for a word for each of the improvisers. Using sheets of paper, a big marking pen, and tape, the MC tapes a word to each improvisers back. Scene is played as the improvisers attempt to get each other to say the word taped to their back.

games.name: Secrets Endowments
games.description: Two improvisers in turn, face upstage plugging their ears. Improviser A asks the audience for a secret about Improviser B, and vice versa. In the course of the scene, each improviser has to endow the other with the appropriate secret.

games.name: Seductions
games.description: In the course of the scene someone is seduced.

games.name: Serious Scene
games.description: Improvisers play a dramatic scene that is serious in nature or incorporates a serious theme. There may be laughs as life is funny but there may be no gags or deliberate jokes.

games.name: Sex Role Reversal
games.description: Men play the women's roles, women play the men's roles.

games.name: Shared Story
games.description: Like a regular Narrated Scene, Internal Narrative, or Typewriter, except that several characters narrate the story from their points of view.

games.name: Should Have Said
games.description: A scene is played and when an offstage improviser calls “Should have said” or rings a bell.  The last improviser to speak must make a substitute for the last offer they made.
games.notes:
Improvisers should not be allowed to get away with variations on the original line. "I'd like a pizza" should not be followed with "I'd like spaghetti".

This game is often misunderstood as a game of "clever ideas". At Unexpected Productions, we like to use it to get through all those ideas until the improviser is out of ideas, and their honest or unplanned offers start to emerge.

games.name: Sideways Scene
games.description: The stage floor is used as a wall in the reality of the scene. The proscenium's "4th wall" becomes the floor of the stage reality. Allows the improvisers to defy gravity and fall to truly gruesome deaths.

games.name: Silent Scene
games.description: Playing a scene in which no words are spoken. Should be played realistically and the improvisers should not find themselves in a position where they might speak to each other.

games.name: Silly-Stinky-Sexy
games.description: Four improvisers are on stage. You consider yourself neutral. Secretly endow each of the other improvisers with either being silly, sexy, or stinky. The scene is then played using the individual designations as your attitude toward the others. Play the scene for as much reality as possible.

games.name: Sing Speak
games.description: As a scene is played, the improviser must begin singing their dialogue when an accompanist begins playing. They return to regular dialogue when the music stops, then sing when music plays, and then speak, etc.

games.name: Slide Show
games.description: A great handle for many different formats. Improvisers pose in non specific poses while narrator explains - vacation, area of expertise, etc.

games.name: Slides
games.description: A scene in which an improviser slides from one state into another and then back again or goes back and forth between two states of being such as high/low status, two emotions, etc.

games.name: Slow Motion Commentary
games.description: Two improvisers perform an everyday activity, in slo-mo, as if part of an Olympic style competition. Two off stage improvisers provide color commentary. Good to avoid the now cliché fight in this scene.

games.name: Soap Opera
games.description: Three improvisers must perform a scene in which one is leaning against something, one is staring at someone, and one is looking out at the audience.
games.notes:
This can be a good exercise to remind people that stage picture is important, and to act with their eyes/gaze.

If performed for an audience, it can be a good idea to ask the audience to make "ooh ooh ooh" noises when the improvisers are failing to embody each of the three requirements.

Add risk by joining other performers in what they are doing, and try to justify the movement. Be surprised by what the physical offers tell you about yourself.

games.name: Solo Scene
games.description: Only one person is allowed on stage. Teammates may provide voices, props, or sound effects.

games.name: Song Circle
games.description: Improvisers form a circle. One at time, they add a musical sound to the circle. After everyone has joined in, the improvisers mingle with each other making their sounds, finding little "jam sessions". At a given signal, they reform the circle in the same starting order. Then one by one, starting with the person who made the first sound, everyone falls silent.

games.name: Song Cue
games.description: As a scene is played, an offstage improviser will occasionally freeze the scene and the last line spoken becomes the title of a song sung by that character. Duets, etc. can be endowed upon the scene.

games.name: Song in a Style
games.description: A single song is sung in a specific style, based on an audience suggestion.
variations: Ballad
Blues
Country Western
Doo-Wop
Teen Angel Song
Teen Death Song
Trucker Song

games.name: Sound Effects
games.description: A tape with randomly placed sound effects is played while scene is being played. Improvisers must incorporate and justify the F/X. A sound improviser may be used in place of a tape.

games.name: SoundScape
games.description: Scene is played, usually without dialogue, while off stage improviser(s) provide sounds for the environment.

games.name: Soundtrack
games.description: A situation is given. Music, changing periodically, sets the mood. Must be justified by the improvisers.

games.name: Speaking at the Same Time
games.description: Improvisers must carry on a scene in which they all must be speaking and silent at the same time.

games.name: Speaking In One Voice
games.description: A scene suggestion is given. Two or more improvisers combine to speak (and move) as one character. Can also be used to narrate or tell a story to the audience.
variations: Two-Headed Expert: Scene where an interview is conducted with an expert comprised of two people that speak in a single voice.

games.name: Speaking In Turn
games.description: Improvisers decide on a speaking order rotation, then play the scene speaking only in that rotation.

games.name: Speck
games.description: An onstage actor plays a scene with a "speck" whose voice is provided by an off stage improviser. The on stage improviser endows the voice ("Wow, a talking bottle cap!") and plays the scene.

games.name: Spell It
games.description: A scene is played in which all lines of dialogue are spelled rather then spoken. They must S-P-E-L-L   O-U-T   E-V-E-R-Y   W-O-R-D.

games.name: Split Focus
games.description: A scene in which the focus alternates between characters and scenes in different areas of the stage. The two scenes may or may not be related, however, some elements of one scene should be incorporated into the other.

games.name: Split Screen
games.description: A location is established for the stage. Imagine that a line is drawn down the center of the location and the two halves of the location are switched. The “center of the stage becomes the stage right and left edges of the playing area. A scene is then played in this environment. When a character crosses “center” they leave the playing area and another improviser enters from the other side playing the same character crossing the room.
variations: The same actors play the same characters so a cross across the room would entail the actor running backstage and reentering on the other side.

games.name: Spoon River
games.description: Improvisers get suggestions for occupations and an attitude; begin the scene by lying on the stage. One by one, they sit up and introduce their characters (who are dead). They recount the circumstances of their lives and deaths, as they tell their stories the tales should weave themselves together.

games.name: Spotlight
games.description: Different scenes take place in different pools of light that are changed at the lighting operator's discretion. When the lights change a new scene begins in the lit area; whenever the lights return to a previous area the scene that took place there previously resumes.

games.name: Stage Directions
games.description: Directions or instructions are written on a deck of cards. The onstage improvisers look at the cards and justifiably follow them while continuing the scene. Directions may be things like, “Be suspicious of one of the characters” “Stand on one foot” Or “Speak in poetic language”

games.name: Standing, Sitting, Kneeling, Lying Down
games.description: A scene in which the improvisers must be standing, sitting, kneeling, or lying down. No two improvisers can be in the same position and all positions must be justified.

games.name: Statues
games.description: Audience members, or other improvisers, mold the body positions of two on stage improvisers. Improvisers begin the scene, justifying their positions. May try to end the scene in the same positions, or having swapped the original positions.

games.name: Status Cards
games.description: Each improviser onstage draws a card from a deck of playing cards without looking at it. They then place the card on their foreheads and play a scene. All the improvisers treat each other with the status they see on the improviser's forehead with aces being high. If it is a two is on someone's head, they are treated with low status; a queen receives very high status treatment, etc.
variations: Each player has multiple cards that they cycle through allowing their status to change over the course of a scene.

games.name: Step Letter Scene
games.description: A word is taken from the audience as a suggestion (Stop). The first improviser has to use that word in a sentence (Stop, don't go there!). The second improviser must change one letter in the word and use it in the second sentence (I just took a step). This then continues (Don't leave without your stew).

games.name: Step Out Narrative
games.description: A scene or story in which any character can step out and share their true feelings or a monologue with the audience.

games.name: Step-Word
games.description: A scene or story that has a sequence of words. For instance you can all say one word sentences, then two word sentences, then three word sentences, then two word sentences, then one word sentences.

games.name: Stimulus Response
games.description: Each improviser gets a simple action that one of the other improvisers will naturally do in a scene (blink, or touch their lips), and something they will do in response (When improviser one blinks, I will sneeze!). None of the improvisers should hear the stimulus or the response of any other player. A scene is then played with the stimuli and responses activated.

games.name: Stop Action Narrative
games.description: A scene starts with a suggestion from the audience. The improvisers begin playing the scene. Periodically, the narrator will stop the scene and ask the audience what happens next in the plot. Question may be informational ("Who calls on the phone?") or interpretive ("Regis is deathly afraid of the next object Mary shows him, what is that object?") The actors on stage should be constantly challenging the narrator with opportunities to stop the narrative in order to ask a question.

games.name: Stop and Go
games.description: Freeze while talking and move in silence. Or vice versa.

games.name: Story Story Die
games.description: Three or four improvisers stand in line on stage. MC/Narrator kneels just downstage of them, facing the line. The MC/Narrator points randomly to individuals in the line. When he points to Improviser 1, Improviser 1 speaks, when he moves to Improviser 2, Improviser 1 stops (mid syllable, if necessary), Improviser 2 picks up the story at exactly the same place. If Improviser 2 stutters, repeats a word or two from Improviser 1, or says something completely incongruous, the audience shouts, "DIE!" The improviser dies and a new story begins. This continues until only one person remains.
variations: Get styles for each one as in Storyline.

Storyline: Story, Story Die, without the deaths. Each improviser may request their own movie style, magazine style, -ism, etc. in which to tell the story. When the finger is pointing at them. The story told is usually a familiar fairy tale.

games.name: Strong Emotions
games.description: Scene is played with actors using assigned emotions.

games.name: Stunt Doubles
games.description: Improvisers begin a scene. At any point during the scene an on stage actor may call out "Stunt Double". That actor is then replaced by his stunt double, who then performs the dangerous or distasteful activities. When the activity is finished the double calls out "First Team", and the original improviser returns to the stage.

games.name: Styles
games.description:
Team plays a short neutral scene. Then play the scene two more times "In The Style Of..." a playwright, a period in history, philosophers, painters, type of architecture, etc.

-isms: Scene played in the style of "-isms" (eg: socialism, cannibalism, etc).
Playwrights: The style of any playwright, e.g. Miller, Brecht, Shakespeare, etc.
Magazines/Newspapers: As in the style of a magazine or newspaper, e.g. National Enquirer, Playboy, Reader's Digest, New York Times, etc.
Movies: Any style of film, e.g. Film Noir, Silent, Western, etc.
variations: Use two emotions

games.name: Subtitles
games.description: Scene begins in gibberish. Offstage improviser "translates" the on stage dialogue into subtitles. Often used with Operas or Foreign Film.

games.name: Superhero Endowments
games.description: Someone is sent out and the remaining improvisers get the name of a brand new superhero. They then get two strengths, and a weakness based on the name. The offstage improviser returns and is told the name of his superhero. Ascene is then played out in which the superhero must guess his strengths and overcome his weakness.

games.name: Swedish Storytelling
games.description: Get suggestions for a big thing, a small thing, and something alive. Tell a story incorporating those three things. This game may also be played by taking three different sentences that then must be incorporated into the scene.

games.name: Tag Team Monologue
games.description: A character monologue in which all the improvisers tag in playing the same single character.

games.name: Tag Team Typewriter
games.description: Same as Typewriter, with several people tagging in and out of the scene. The typist who is tagged out might replace the actor who does the tagging.

games.name: The Moon
games.description: Improvisers play a scene as though they have very little gravity. This game works best with a mover (see Moving Bodies) to help with the weightlessness.

games.name: The Moon
games.description: Improvisers play a scene as though they have very little gravity. This game works best with a mover to help with the weightlessness.

games.name: Three Lines
games.description: Choose three lines of dialogue, perhaps famous, perhaps not, which must be used somewhere in the scene.

games.name: Three Scene
games.description: Scene is played in three parts. A “neutral” scene is played. It then repeated two times with a new style or piece of information.
variations: Chapters: A scene is played in three parts as if from different chapters of a book, usually the first chapter, a middle chapter, and the last chapter.
Ratings Board: The first scene is done with a "G" rating. That same scene is recreated again but as though it were rated PG (or PG-13) the next one is rated "R."
Through the Ages: Similar to a Styles scene. Get three periods in history then play the scene as if it took place in those time periods.

games.name: Timed Scene
games.description: A scene that takes place in a specific amount of time (Deaths In A Minute, Epic In A Minute, Two Minute Status Transfer, etc.). Or the scene can be played in the time it takes to complete an activity (Scene That Takes Place in the Same Amount of Time It Takes to Recite the Alphabet Backwards, In The Time It Takes To Walk Around the Theater Five Times, Player to Shave, etc). The key is to find the most appropriate method of timing that will serve the scene and not simply be a gag.

games.name: Timed Styles
games.description: A short scene is played. Then the accelerated scene is repeated in different styles as many times as possible within a three-minute time limit.

games.name: Torture Your Teammate
games.description: All members of team except one block, wimp, waffle, do bad mime, all forms of bad improv. One "straight" improviser must justify everything - keeping the storyline strong.

games.name: Town Meeting
games.description: A topic is taken from the audience and an improviser opens a “Town Meeting” on that subject. They field questions and comments from fellow improvisers and audience members playing the population of the town.
variations: Play as a timed endowment guessing game.

games.name: Transfers
games.description: Two improvisers start a scene with emotions, styles, opposite status and over the course of the scene they switch. This is usually played as a timed scene.

games.name: Triptych
games.description: Three short, unconnected scenes are played. The improvisers play an extension of their original narratives in the same performance order, making minimal references to one or both of the other scenes. Scenes are played a third time gradually incorporating offers from the other stories. The ninth (and last) scene should connect all the scenes.

games.name: True Feelings
games.description: Improviser(s) play a scene speaking their true feelings as improvisers in the scene. Important for the improvisers to be truthful with their feelings.

games.name: Two Chairs
games.description: The improvisers play a scene based on any location where two chairs would be found.

games.name: Two Rooms
games.description: The stage is divided in two and each half assigned a room in which separate scenes take place.

games.name: Two, Too, To
games.description: The following blanks are filled by the audience: Two_________, To _______, Too_______. A scene then is played incorporating the suggestions.

games.name: Typewriter
games.description: One improviser sits at an imaginary 'typewriter', typing a story, while the other actors act out the story. Both actors and typist are responsible for endowing the story with narrative line.

games.name: Understudy
games.description: An improviser leaves the stage and does not watch the scene. A scene is played to a point and one of the characters falls ill. The offstage “understudy” is then called upon to recreate the scene and/or pick the scene up from where it was with no knowledge of what happened the first time.

games.name: Using Character of Plot Line From the Previous Scene
games.description: Title pretty much says it all.

games.name: Verse
games.description: This scene is played entirely in verse. Unless stated the verse DOES NOT need to be rhymed couplets. If you do rhymed couplets you may rhyme yourself, or set up your partner. Haiku, Shakespeare, Iambic Pentameter, etc. are all permissible.

games.name: Virtual Reality
games.description: An audience member (or several) are brought to the stage and assigned an improviser. During the course of the scene, the audience member moves and the improviser must mimic their movements and justify them in the context of the scene.

games.name: Visualization
games.description: An improviser closes their eyes and visualizes a seashore. Don't have them think about it, just have them tell what they see. If they see a house ask them what's inside? Who's there? Continue to ask them what they see and have them describe it in detail. They shouldn't have to choose anything, simply use their strong imaginations.

games.name: Wallpaper Drama
games.description: Improvisers begin a scene. At the discretion of an off stage improviser, "Positive", "Negative", or "Neutral" are called and slowly effect the emotional content of the scene on stage accordingly.
variations: No off stage caller, the improvisers on stage move through levels of neutral, positive, and negative at their own discretion.

games.name: What Are You Doing?
games.description: Improviser 1 begins an action, (eg: jumping rope). Improviser 2 says, "What are you doing?" Improviser 1 says something OTHER than jumping rope (e.g. "Building a bird house.") Improviser 2 begins building a bird house, improviser 1 asks 2, "What are you doing." and so on. Response speed is a must, as is making the action as different from the response as possible.

games.name: What Comes Next?
games.description: An improviser takes the stage and asks, "What happens first?", then does whatever the audience has replied, then they ask “What comes next?”. The goal is to create narrative. This works best if you show the audience that blocking or clever suggestions will get them nowhere. If you train the audience to do this, they will understand it's a skill. If the audience groans at a suggestion, go back and get a different suggestion.
variations: Player ask for step by step instructions.
Player only asks for help when stuck

This game can also be played with a committee of four or five giving the suggestions. The committee will usually feel pressured and make wimpy choices. If the audience feels the committee has failed, the committee may be replaced. The committee should take their time and try to get into trouble. Demand that the first eight or nine suggestions be positive and advance the story. They want to set a routine and then break it, not delay it.

games.name: What If ____
games.description: Audience fills in the blank. For example, "What if money really did grow on trees?"
variations: Same idea.
Without (a) ______

games.name: With Only Questions
games.description: Do you understand this challenge? Can you tell that no statements are allowed? Can this be explained anymore clearly?
variations: Opposite challenge.
Without Questions

games.name: Word Ball
games.description: Improvisers stand in a circle. One improviser "tosses" any word they want to anybody else in the circle, that person in turn "tosses" another free associated word to another person in the circle. This warm up should be played at a fast pace and the improvisers should not think ahead, simply free associate on the word they're tossed.

games.name: Word Pattern
games.description: A word is taken from the audience (Dog), and a scene is played in which the improvisers have to begin each line of dialogue using the next letter in the word. (“Doug has to be the right one.” “Over my dead Body!” “Get out of the way!” “Don't touch me.” Oh, come on!” “Go away”, etc.)

games.name: Word-at-a-Time Expert
games.description: Three or more improvisers stand or sit in a line. They are a single expert on a subject. They speak one word at a time. The subject is given by the audience. The improvisers must speak in order, one word at a time.
games.notes: An extra improviser may act as a moderator. They may invite the audience to ask questions. This is a great game to invite an audience member to play, who may sit between two more experienced improvisers who can help keep the game going.

games.name: Word-at-a-Time Story
games.description: Improvisers stand in a circle. They begin to tell a story a word at a time around the circle.
variations: Have the mutant narrate a story that is acted out by other improvisers.

Mutants: Two improvisers tell a story, alternating one word at a time, acting out the action of the story as it is told. Story should be kept in the present tense so that action is accomplished rather than talked about.
Offstage player calls out numbers at random and that's how many words each improviser uses.

Step-Word Scene: A verbal restriction scene. Scene begins with a 1 word sentence. Next sentence has two words. Then three. Proceeds up to a 10 word sentence, then to a 9 word sentence. Back to a final 1 word sentence.

Step-Word Story: A combination of Word-at-a-Time Story, and Step-Word Scene. Improvisers tell a story around a circle. The first time around the circle each improviser is allowed one word. The second time around, they are allowed two words, then three, etc. up to five. Then descend from five to one word circles. When the circle finishes the cycle the story should end. Again that pattern is 1-2-3-4-5-4-3-2-1-end

Word-at-a-Time Scene: Like Mutants, except each improviser plays a separate character. If one character speaks, the dialogue is provided by all the improvisers onstage - one word at a time. It is vital in this scene to have strong character voices for each person in the scene, since all the actors onstage are providing dialogue, the voices serve to distinguish the characters from one another.

games.name: Yes, And…
games.description: Every line of dialogue begins with the words, "Yes, and..."Can be played as a brainstorming meeting for marketing a new product. The goal is to absolutely support your partners' suggestions and to experience being supported. Excellent workshop game.
variations: Same as above, rather than demonstrating support, it demonstrates creative waffling.
Yes, But…

games.name: Zones
games.description: Improvisers divide stage into quadrants and take audience suggestions (ex. -emotions, styles, status, attitudes) for each quadrant. Improvisers play the scene, changing their style as they change stage quadrants. Changes must be justifiable.
variations: An order is established to the words, sounds, silences which is maintained by the onstage players.
Words, Sounds, Silence: In one quadrant, improvisers may speak, in another they may make noises, in the third, they are silent.

games.name: Zulu
games.description:
Several improvisers line up and a product category is taken form the audience such as cars or furniture polishes. When the MC points at one of the improvisers, they must come up with a fictitious brand name for the item or the audience yells, “Die”.

Played until only one improviser is left. Best played if sentences are not allowed. For instance a fictitious furniture polish named “Shine Bright” is acceptable while “Gee, my furniture looks terrific” is not.
